bug.short_desc: Logs flooded with cdc_ether kevent dropped messages
bug.cf_doc_type: If docs needed, set a value

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem: After upgrading to F25 Beta, the logs on my ThinkPad X1 Yoga are getting flooded with the message: "cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth0: kevent 11 may have been dropped"
The first error is for kevent 12, subsequent errors are all kevent 11.
The only recourse is to unload the module, and blacklist it.
Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable): $ uname -a Linux x1yoga 4.8.1-1.fc25.x86_64 #1 SMP Fri Oct 7 14:38:22 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
How reproducible: Did not happen with F24, new issue with F25 Beta
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Boot F25 on ThinkPad X1 Yogo 2. 3.
Actual results: $ dmesg |grep cdc|head -n 50 [ 4.415930] usbcore: registered new interface driver cdc_ncm [ 4.417803] usbcore: registered new interface driver cdc_wdm [ 4.433977] cdc_mbim 1-2:1.12: cdc-wdm0: USB WDM device [ 4.434150] cdc_mbim 1-2:1.12 wwan0: register 'cdc_mbim' at usb-0000:00:14.0-2, CDC MBIM, f6:9c:96:2e:b9:4e [ 4.434259] usbcore: registered new interface driver cdc_mbim [ 4.435345] cdc_mbim 1-2:1.12 wwp0s20f0u2i12: renamed from wwan0 [ 5.711356] cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth0: register 'cdc_ether' at usb-0000:00:14.0-4.1.3, CDC Ethernet Device, 00:50:b6:d3:00:ed [ 5.712875] usbcore: registered new interface driver cdc_ether [ 7.529546] cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth0: kevent 12 may have been dropped [ 7.546980] cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth0: kevent 11 may have been dropped [ 7.610989] cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth0: kevent 11 may have been dropped [ 7.675249] cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth0: kevent 11 may have been dropped [ 7.739681] cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth0: kevent Started seeing what I assume to be the same issue from cdc_ether on F24 after updating to the 4.8.4 and 4.8.6 kernel. No such issues when booting with 4.7.9. Did not notice this for a while because network was still working, it's just dmesg getting flooded. This on a Lenovo X1 Carbon 3rd gen using a OneLink Pro dock (Ethernet over USB).
My current workaround is blacklisting cdc_ether in /etc/modprobe.d, which causes r8152 to be used instead. I had been doing it the other way around for some time (i.e. blacklisting r8152) due to losing connectivity when redocking, if both modules were loaded. Don't recall the details anymore, but some issue with "link is not ready".
$ uname -a Linux audroe 4.8.6-201.fc24.x86_64 #1 SMP Thu Nov 3 14:38:57 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
$ modprobe.d# lsusb Bus 001 Device 002: ID 8087:8001 Intel Corp. Bus 001 Device 001: ID 1d6b:0002 Linux Foundation 2.0 root hub Bus 003 Device 005: ID 17ef:304f Lenovo Bus 003 Device 004: ID 0451:8041 Texas Instruments, Inc. Bus 003 Device 003: ID 2109:0812 VIA Labs, Inc. VL812 Hub Bus 003 Device 002: ID 2109:0812 VIA Labs, Inc. VL812 Hub Bus 003 Device 001: ID 1d6b:0003 Linux Foundation 3.0 root hub Bus 002 Device 013: ID 04f2:b45d Chicony Electronics Co., Ltd Bus 002 Device 011: ID 138a:0017 Validity Sensors, Inc. Fingerprint Reader Bus 002 Device 005: ID 04f3:012d Elan Microelectronics Corp. Bus 002 Device 003: ID 1199:a001 Sierra Wireless, Inc. Bus 002 Device 010: ID 046d:c52b Logitech, Inc. Unifying Receiver Bus 002 Device 008: ID 046d:c044 Logitech, Inc. LX3 Optical Mouse Bus 002 Device 006: ID 1a40:0101 Terminus Technology Inc. Hub Bus 002 Device 009: ID 17ef:304e Lenovo Bus 002 Device 007: ID 0451:8043 Texas Instruments, Inc. Bus 002 Device 004: ID 2109:2812 VIA Labs, Inc. VL812 Hub Bus 002 Device 002: ID 2109:2812 VIA Labs, Inc. VL812 Hub Bus 002 Device 001: ID 1d6b:0002 Linux Foundation 2.0 root hub
lshw excerpt (after blacklisting cdc_ether): *-usb:1 description: Generic USB device product: ThinkPad Dock Giga vendor: Lenovo physical id: 3 bus info: usb@3:3.1.3 version: 30.00 serial: 0050B67CF86F capabilities: usb-3.00 configuration: driver=r8152 maxpower=144mA speed=5000Mbit/s

I can confirm this on Arch, Lenovo X1 Yoga, ObeLink+ Dock:
$ uname -a Linux funkarch 4.8.12-3-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Thu Dec 8 16:10:23 CET 2016 x86_64 GNU/Linux
$ journalctl -r Dec 09 12:19:12 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:12 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:12 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:12 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:12 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:12 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:12 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:12 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:11 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:11 funkarch kernel: cdc_ether 2-4.1.3:2.0 eth1: kevent 11 may have been dropped Dec 09 12:19:11 funkarch kernel: net_ratelimit: 69 callbacks suppressed

operate at Full Speed (12Mbps) Device can operate at High Speed (480Mbps) Device can operate at SuperSpeed (5Gbps) bFunctionalitySupport 2 Lowest fully-functional device speed is High Speed (480Mbps) bU1DevExitLat 10 micro seconds bU2DevExitLat 2047 micro seconds can't get debug descriptor: Resource temporarily unavailable Device Status: 0x0000
According to what I've read this should be posted to the linux-usb vger.kernel list however I can't search that list as gmane seems to be still recovering from it's recent bork and I don't use NNTP for anything so frankly don't want to install stuff just to post this. Could the kernel maintainer upstream this to the correct location as it's not just a Lenovo issue.

Sorry...forgot to add.
Linux nohost.somedomain 4.8.12-200.fc24.x86_64 #1 SMP Fri Dec 2 18:45:50 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

For me, this problem seems fixed after updating to kernel 4.8.14-300.fc25.x86_64.

*********** MASS BUG UPDATE ************** We apologize for the inconvenience. There is a large number of bugs to go through and several of them have gone stale. Due to this, we are doing a mass bug update across all of the Fedora 25 kernel bugs.
Fedora 25 has now been rebased to 4.9.3-200.fc25. Please test this kernel update (or newer) and let us know if you issue has been resolved or if it is still present with the newer kernel.
If you have moved on to Fedora 26, and are still experiencing this issue, please change the version to Fedora 26.
If you experience different issues, please open a new bug report for those.
Closing this bug report as I no longer get the flood of kevent 11 messages.
